I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away.….”As each year draws to a close, emotions you&nbsphave tried to control finally take grip. I feel torn – from the joy at returning to my&nbsploved ones and the heartache for those I&nbsphad to leave behind. I am staring at my canvas camera bags, which sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world.&nbspNow they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away…Here I have compiled a collection of photographs and memories, comprising the stories of some of the most marginalised children in the world.Winter: Abdul, a Syrian refugee aged 10, is seated in a makeshift shelter, perched high among&nbspthe rugged snowy mountain caps of Arsal, Lebanon. He holds his father’s hand as they both huddle&nbspby the stove for warmth. He has the haunting stare of a boy who knows he is&nbspgoing to die, an expression that cuts through the paraffin haze of the dark room as temperatures fall below zero. Mohammed, his father, gaunt from grief, explains&nbsphis son is two years overdue for an operation that could save his life.&nbspWith no means to finance it, he raises&nbsphis hands to the sky in hope that his prayers would be answered.&nbspI remember waiting to see my doctor as a child. I knew my turn would come Abdul knew his would not.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpring:&nbspVenezuelan refugees who once ate together as families around their own tables&nbspnow eat from rubbish bins on their hands and knees to survive the crisis in their country. All the while, their president publicly feasts&nbspin lavish establishments. title: highs lows politics 2019 brexit
story: But amid all the chaos and conniving,  had its comic moments in the ­corridors of power. Sunday Political Editor David Wooding hands out his annual gongs – The Wooders.Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson deluded herself she would be the next PM and toured the land in a coach bearing her giant mugshot on the side.But she didn’t even manage to win her own seat back.At least it cheered up the second most annoying party leader, the SNP’s Nicola Sturgeon, who punched the air in glee at claiming her Scots rival’s scalp.You wait two years for a Labour star to jump ship — then he does it twice in a few weeks.Following his aborted leadership bid, Chuka Umunna launched a new party, Change UK.But he became so fond of change, he did it again and joined the Lib Dems.Now he’s coping with more change after voters booted him out.Expelled left-winger Derek Hatton is readmitted into the Labour Party after a -year wait — only to be kicked out again  hours later.Comeback king Nigel Farage launched the Brexit Party.But within hours, pranksters registered its email address as a porn site.He was swamped with offers from East European women offering a “stress-free” massage.Bet he needed a rub down after his party bombed in the election.John Bercow stood down as Commons Speaker after ten years and was then accused of demanding £million to appear on TV’s I’m A Celebrity.He denied the claims but Brexit-backing MPs would happily have paid Remainer Bercow handsomely to get him out of the Westminster jungle.Naughty-but-nice Trade Secretary Liz Truss attended The Big Sausage event in Norfolk, saying it was, “ticking rather a lot of my boxes”.Asked to try a Gloucester Old Spot banger, she enthused: “That’s one of the best offers I’ve had all year.”It perhaps explains why Liz enjoyed working in a well-hung Parliament so much.Housing minister James Brokenshire showed off his new kitchen which boasts FOUR matching ovens.The revelation must have left the PM wondering where to put his “oven-ready” Brexit deal.It prompted one stunned MP to ask: “Is he running a pizza business on the side ”A miserable year for Jeremy Corbyn as his party and football team tanked.After his election defeat, the Labour leader assured fellow Arsenal fans he wouldn’t be applying for the vacant job of Gunners team boss.Just as well, as he’d probably borrow £billion to buy more left wingers and strikers but remain neutral on whether to play in Europe.Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg was dubbed “insolent” and “insufferable” when he reclined almost horizontally on the Commons’ green benches during a late-night Brexit debate.He refused to budge, amid cries of, “Sit up, man!”But the posh wind-up merchant smiled and nodded when one angry MP sarcastically suggested he should be supplied with a pillow.Spoon-bending psychic Uri Geller vowed to use his “telepathic powers” to stop Jeremy Corbyn becoming PM.After the election, he claimed he influenced Boris Johnson’s landslide victory by giving him a spoon energised with “mind positivity”.Chris “Failing” Grayling quit as Transport Secretary after a string of Brexit planning blunders — including awarding a cross-Channel ferry contract to a firm with no ships.Labour Deputy Leader Tom Watson shed st in two years by giving up sugar and taking up exercise.He became so thin that Corbynista “assassins” missed their target in a plot to oust him.Slimline Watson then decided to cast off his ­political baggage and quit as an MP.Shadow Education Secretary Angela ­Rayner has been showered with compliments about her figure after going on a “half-portions” diet.She quipped: “Fat birds don’t win elections.”Neither do slim turkeys when Corbyn is leader.Boris Johnson almost botched his leadership bid after a “screaming row” with his girlfriend over a wine stain on her sofa.Police were called by neighbours who reported “a lot of smashing” from the home he shared with Carrie Symonds.What happened next remains secret.Perhaps it was a ­cover-up — by an upholstery firm.Cops ordered a McDonald’s outlet to stop selling milkshakes during a rally by Nigel Farage in Edinburgh — in case they were used as missiles by customers.The Brexit Party boss completed the visit unscathed, only to be “milkshaked” in Newcastle.Loveable No pup Dilyn outshines ­Cameron, May, Johnson and even Larry the Downing Street cat.The seven-month-old Jack Russell-cross from an animal rescue charity moved in with BoJo’s girlfriend Carrie and always steals the show at official receptions.A real yappy ending.Hapless Karen Bradley admitted she didn’t believe a word she said as Northern Ireland Secretary.She dropped a clanger by saying that killings by the military and police during The Troubles were not crimes — then rowed back, insisting: “I want to be very clear. I do not believe what I said. That is not my view.”Boris Johnson brandished a kipper at his leadership hustings.But his claim that he couldn’t have it delivered by post because of EU rules proved very fishy.Channel  replaced no-shows Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage with melting ice sculptures during a debate on climate change.Viewers probably judged their performance to be less drippy than Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson’s.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson was sacked after an inquiry into who leaked details of a National Security Council meeting over plans to allow Chinese telecoms giant Huawei to help build Britain’s G network.Downing Street said the PM had, “lost confidence in his ability to serve”, but he soon ed to Cabinet.All sounds a bit, er, phoney.Boris likened himself to The Incredible Hulk as he vowed to break free from EU shackles.But when he showed schoolkids an image of the superhero during a school visit, a boy pointed at the huge muscles and said: “You’ve got boobies.”She failed to secure a Brexit deal and lost the Tories’ majority.Yet Theresa May soldiered on with everyone against her.When toppled, she didn’t quit Parliament in a huff or carp endlessly from the backbenches but showed more loyalty to her successor than he gave to her.Mrs May could prove to be the finest ex-PM Britain ever had.Remainer lawyer Gina Miller blew thousands trying to stop Brexit — but unwittingly helped deliver it.Her court victory gave Brexit-blocker MPs the right to vote down Theresa May’s “soft” departure deal.But it set off a chain of events that put Bojo in No with a majority big enough to force through a much cleaner Brexit. Thanks, Gina.They spent the past three and a half years plotting to stop Brexit at every turn.But at the General Election, voters sent them a clear message: Leave Parliament.So good riddance to Dominic Grieve, Anna Soubry, David Gauke, Laura Pidcock, Chuka Umunna, Jo Swinson, Philip Lee, Antoinette Sandbach and Sam Gyimah. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady salute inspirational women
story: I am ready to ring in the new with heartfelt enthusiasm. But just before we say goodbye to this year, I’ve been thinking about all the brilliant women who did brave, groundbreaking and seriously inspiring things in .Here, in no particular order, are my pick of those who really stood out — and hopefully will continue to do so for some time to come.It’s been a very mixed year for her. The country has had a tumultuous time, going to the polls and with two Prime Ministers.Her grandsons were apparently feuding and she had to be seen to be laying down the law to Prince Andrew.History may well judge  as her second annus horribilis.Yet somehow, this amazing woman has been the very definition of a dignied, strong and steady leader, offering us the stability and reassurance we as a country so desperately need.Yes, I know women’s football has been going on for years.But  was the year our Lionesses put it firmly on the map.Not only that, they have also inspired a generation of girls to get their boots on and play, knowing they can be just as good as boys on the pitch.So although it’s a shame it’s taken this long, we all owe them a debt of gratitude.I have long admired Emily for asking the hard questions on BBC’s Newsnight.But this year, in the face of the extreme hotting-up of Brexit, culminating in December’s General Election, her coverage has been second to none .Then her grilling of Prince Andrew in November was a masterclass in conducting a good interview — clinical, forensic and meticulous, without a hint of deference.Never shouty or confrontational, she gave Andrew the space to show himself to the public so they could make up their own minds about his culpability in his relationship with convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.She also somehow managed not to make herself the storyalthough when Prince Andrew described Epstein’s actions as “unbecoming”, she took the chance to look as disgusted as we all feel.“Unbecoming ” she said. “He was a sex offender.”In short, she nailed him.That photo of her wearing the world’s most beautul dress, martini and cigarette in hand at the Emmys after-party, said it all.Earlier in the night she had won three of the four Emmys she was up for — just more in a long line of awards and accolades this year, during which she proved the brilliance of Fleabag was not a one-off.Her sharp, witty and totally original writing on Killing Eve showed she is seriously clever as well as unbelievably glamorous.And her portrayal of women is original, transgressive and totally refreshing.No wonder she was drafted in to give her input and perspective on the next Bond movie.I have a feeling that in  we will realise Phoebe Waller-Bridge is only just getting started.She has had her first baby, conducted her first royal tour and guest edited Vogue. Oh, and she met Beyonce.All in all, not a bad year! She has also managed to consistently put on a brave and happy face while on the receiving end of more criticism than most of us could stand.But it is her le-long passion for and commitment to feminism I admire most.On International Women’s Day, she said: “Men can understand that they can be feminists,” and should feel comfortable about women being by their side, rather than behind them.As we know all too well, not everyone likes a strong woman. But because she is strong, my view is that she will win over her critics in the end.Leave it to the women to organise, unite and provide support to local women in their community and provide support for those affected by the terrible tragedy of the Grenfell fire.Their aim is to provide a networking  and discussion forums for women and arrange positive actions and initiatives that will help the community. But above all, they want to remember — which is why they organise a monthly silent walk in memory of their “lost angels”.My heart breaks for them that they have to do this.But what a brilliant reminder of the power of organisation and women coming together to support each other.Earlier this year, at an equal pay tribunal brought against the BBC by the TV and radio presenter, Samira said she: “Could not understand how pay for me, a woman, could be so much lower than Jeremy Vine, a man, for presenting very similar programmes and doing very similar work . . .“I just ask why the BBC thinks I am worth only a sixth of the value of the work of a man for doing a very similar job.”On behalf of every woman who has felt she should have said something, should have done something, should have spoken out, stood up or walked out when they knew they were being paid less than men in similar roles, but who felt they had no choice but to put up with it, I salute her.I also want to give a mention to the captain of the US women’s soccer team.Yes, she is a great player. But people have lined up to criticise her because she is another strong woman who seems genuinely not to care what people think of her and what she says.They describe her in the US as a “badass” and there is no doubt that she is outspoken on every issue going.But it is her ongoing campaign to normalise gay relationships in sport that really resonates with me.Working in a sport where no male has ever come out as gay while playing in the Premier League, it seems sad — and unacceptable — that people can’t be open about being gay.I think Megan is helping to change that, though.Asked in an interview how it felt to lead the US team, she replied: “Go gays!”She continued: “You can’t win a championship without gays on your team. It’s never been done before. Ever.”Could any collection of amazing women be complete without a mention of the -year-old schoolgirl who has started an international revolution Everything this young woman has done — and she has done more than anyone I can think of to raise awareness about the climate emergency — has been made so much more impressive because of her tenacity in the face of such extreme criticism.Most of the youngster’s critics seem to be men of a certain age who are, I guess, threatened by someone so young and female being so bold, opinionated and unconcerned about what they think.Amazingly, the insults and attacks seem only to have empowered her further and fuelled her determination to make the world listen to what we need to do to try to stop climate change in its tracks.A slip of a girl — and a teen at that — is changing the world.Bravely, and in the face of extreme confrontation at times, she has created a movement where millions around the world follow her and listen to her.She has turned down many accolades because she is not in it for the adulation. She really just wants to make change happen. Truly inspirational.A bit like female Prime Ministers, female newspaper editors are a rarer breed than male ones.Women have such an important role to play in journalism and in fighting for equality.And now, for the first time in  years, there will be a female editor of the Financial Times, which really is groundbreaking, given the paper has been such a bastion of male power for so long.Roula is going to do a magnicent job, not least because she is so focused on increasing newsroom ersity and attracting more female readers, which gives her an obvious spot among my Women of the Year.And a final mention must go to Dr Nyla Raja, purely for personal reasons.She has transformed my skin this year.Everyone needs a great facial and a little help . . . and boy, does she deliver!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: matt ridley we are saving planet
story: Global inequality has been plunging as Africa and Asia experience faster economic growth than Europe and North America. Child mortality is at record low levels. Famine virtually went extinct. Malaria, polio and heart disease are declining.Ever since I wrote The Rational Optimist, in , I’ve been faced with, “what about. . . ” questions: What about the great recession, the euro crisis, Syria, Ukraine, Donald Trump  How can I possibly say that things are getting better, given all that The answer is: Because bad things happen while the world still gets better.That is to say, our population and economy would grow, but we would learn how to reduce what we take from the planet. And so it has proved.Scientist Andrew McAfee documented this in his book More From Less, showing how some nations are beginning to use less metal, less water and less land.This does not quite fit with what the Extinction Rebellion lot are telling us.But the next time you hear Sir David Attenborough say: “Anyone who thinks you can have infinite growth on a planet with finite resources is either a madman or an economist,” ask him this: “But whateconomic growth means using less stuff, not more ”For example, a drink can contains  grams of aluminium, much of it recycled. In  it contained  grams.Substituting the former for the latter is a contribution to economic growth, but it reduces the resources consumed per drink.As for Britain, our consumption of “stuff” probably peaked around the turn of the century. The evidence is there.In  Chris Goodall, an investor in electric vehicles, published research showing the UK was now using not just relatively less stuff every year, but absolutely less.Events have since vindicated his thesis. The quantity of all resources consumed per person in Britain fell by a third between  and , from . tonnes to . tonnes.That’s a faster decline than the increase in the number of people, so it means fewer resources consumed overall.Think about your own home. Mobile phones have the computing power of room-sized computers of the s. I use mine instead of a camera, radio, torch, compass, map, calendar, watch, CD player newspaper and a pack of cards.LED light bulbs consume about a quarter as much electricity as incandescent bulbs for the same light. Modern buildings generally contain less steel and more of it is recycled. Offices use much less paper.Even in cases when the use of stuff is not falling, it is rising more slowly than expected.For instance, how much water the world consumed in  was half as much as experts in the s predicted. Inventiveness allowed more efficient irrigation for agriculture, the biggest user of water.Until recently, most economists assumed these improvements were almost always in vain, becauseyou cut the cost of something, people would just use more of it. Make lights less energy hungry and people leave them on for longer.But Andrew McAfee argues that doesn’t hold up. Suppose you switch from incandescent to LED bulbs in your house and save about three-quarters of your electricity bill for lighting. You might leave more lights on for longer, but surely not four times as long.Efficiencies in agriculture mean the world is now approaching “peak farmland”. Despite the growing number of people and their demand for more and better food, the productivity of agriculture is rising so fast that human needs can be supplied by a shrinking amount of land.In , Jesse Ausubel, of The Rockefeller University in New York, and his colleagues argued that thanks to modern technology, we use  per cent less land to produce a given quantity of food compared with  years ago.By  it is estimated that an area the size of India will have been released from the plough and the cow.Perhaps the most surprising statistic is that Britain is using steadily less energy.John Constable, of the Global Warming Policy Forum think tank, points out that although the UK’s economy has almost trebled since , and our population is up by  per cent, energy consumption has fallen by almost ten per cent.This is not necessarily good news, Constable argues. Although the improving energy efficiency of light bulbs, planes and cars is part of the story, it also means we are importing more embedded energy in products, having driven much of our steel, aluminium and chemical industries abroad with some of the world’s highest energy prices.In fact, all this energy-saving might cause problems.Innovation requires experiments . Experiments require energy. So cheap energy is crucial.Thus, energy may be the one resource that a prospering population should be using more of.Since its inception, the environmental movement has been obsessed by finite resources. The two books that kicked off the green industry in the early s, The Limits To Growth, in America, and BlueprintFor Survival, in Britain, both lamented the imminent exhaustion of metals, minerals and fuels.The Limits To Growth predicted thatgrowth continued, the world would run out of gold, mercury, silver, tin, zinc, copper and lead well before . School textbooks soon echoed these claims.This caused the economist Julian Simon to challenge the ecologist Paul Ehrlich to a bet that five metalswould cost less in  than in .The Stone Age did not end for lack of stone, Simon said, arguing that we would find substitutesmetals grew scarce.Simon won the bet easily, and Ehrlich sniped that: “The one thing we’ll never run out of is imbeciles.”To this day, none of those metals has signicantly risen in price nor run out. A modern irony is that many green policies advocated now would actually reverse the trend towards using less stuff.A wind farm requires far more concrete and steel than a system based on gas. Environmental opposition to nuclear power has hindered the generating system that needs the least land, least fuel and least steel or concrete per megawatt.Burning wood instead of coal in power stations means the exploitation of more land — and even higher emissions. Organic farming uses more land than conventional methods.Technology has put us on a path to a cleaner, greener planet. We don’t need to veer in a new direction. To do so risks retarding progress.As we enter the third decade of this century, I’ll make a prediction.By the end of it we will see less poverty, less child mortality, less land devoted to agriculture.There will be more tigers, whales, forests and nature reserves. Britons will be richer and each of us will use fewer resources.The global political future may be uncertain, but the environmental and technological trends are pretty clear — and pointing in the right direction. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony blair labour pension vanish
story: Army veterans, teachers, police, paramedics and firefighters are victims of a scam that went undetected for a decade.They had trustingly transferred savings into rogue schemes which were enrolled with HMRC and the Pensions Regulator, giving them an air of legitimacy. Employers such as the MoD and the NHS had said they were safe.But it simply wasn’t true . . . and at least  rogue operators were free to roam in a “scammer’s paradise”.To add insult to injury, the victims — some of whom have reported feeling suicidal — are now being fined for unknowingly participating in these schemes, which broke tax laws.And who’s to blame  Tony Blair and his Labour government, who relaxed rules around HMRC enrolment in , allowing dodgy pension schemes to sign up with virtually no checks.This was supposed to bring “security, dignity and comfort in old age”. Instead it has unleashed a nightmare.Perhaps instead of lecturing us on Brexit, Blair should reflect on his devastating legacy.IN her bid to become the next Labour leader, Rebecca Long-Bailey has promised “progressive patriotism”.It sounds as nonsensical as the party’s economic policies. After all, there’s nothing “progressive” about this vile, anti-semitic version of the party.Nor is there anything “patriotic” about Long-Bailey’s loyalty to Jeremy Corbyn, the man who counts Hamas, Hezbollah and the IRA as his friends.So it comes as no surprise that Corbyn’s cronies are apparently trying to shorten the Labour leadership contest in order to boost Long-Bailey’s chances and “stitch-up” other hopefuls.Her proclamation of patriotism shows utter desperation.Labour spent years treating anyone who’s proud to be British as lowle scum, only to have that backfire on them at the election.Many are proud of this country and enthusiastic about Brexit.It’s a bit too late for Corbynistas to pretend they feel the same.IT looks set to be a very happy New Year for many British workers.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced that the minimum wage for over s will rise by p to £. an hour in April.After years of “Spreadsheet Phil” Hammond and his Brexit fearmongering, this is exactly the boost Britain needs — both for the economy and spirit.So let’s join the three million who’ll be toasting Mr Javid on New Year’s Eve. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new decade improve politics
story: But let’s be frank. Things can only improve on the last four years of anger, ision and political paralysis.A period which should have been pivotal to our country saw it barely governed at all. That all changed at pm on December .Boris Johnson’s thumping election win gives us the greatest opportunity for radical renewal since at least .That means finally achieving Brexit  days from now and then, we hope, rapidly ­striking trade deals with Brussels and the world’s greatest economies.It means a dramatic, imaginative ­Budget to turbo-charge both those “left-behind” regions which voted Tory for the first time and the wider economy.We share too the  vision of our readers: For huge NHS investment to continue and a long-term social care solution be put in place.That tax breaks and rate cuts must renew our dilapidated High Streets and help small firms thrive and create jobs.That rough sleeping must be slashed, even ended. That wages must be driven up and food banks rendered redundant.That the Tories must continue striving for a cleaner environment without ­caving in to economy-wrecking panic.And we of course share the desire for a kinder, more united country — echoed by the open letter from faith, ­culture, sport and business leaders.The Sun is optimistic about that too.In fact we do not agree we have suffered a “decade of ision”. Yes, it was tough financially. But we were far from ided at, say, the  Olympics.The anger in our Parliament, offices, factories and homes was caused by Brexit, specically by some Remainers’ refusal to accept defeat, and by a Labour Party engulfed by the hostile hard-left.The Brexit heat is fast dissipating now. Boris’s triumph saw to that. Many Remainers are making their peace with it . . . and even seeing its opportunities.Which leaves but one obstacle to the national healing.No one has done more to ide us than Jeremy Corbyn, his thuggish, often anti-Semitic followers and his obnoxious media apologists.Their relentless hatred and dishonest demonisation of opponents toxied both political discourse and Labour’s election fortunes.Yet none of the contenders to replace Corbyn grasps this reality: They can remain a Twitter-obsessed, Tory-hating clique of middle-class Marxist posers calling each other “comrade” but disconnected from working people.Or be viable, mainstream contenders for Government. But not both.Will they make the right choice  It’s January , , and we live in hope.We are far more sure that Britain, fully independent for the first time in  years, will enjoy a golden decade in the ’s.Happy New Year to you all! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg shift opinions
story: Thanks to the -year-old Swedish climate change campaigner many more of us are eco-warriors these days. Whichever box we ticked in the election, millions of us vote green with our lestyles.A recent survey of Sun readers showed  per cent recognise climate change is real and that  per cent of us worry more about our environmental impact now than they did five years ago.And  per cent of Sun readers want to make their habits greener still.Some of them make their voices heard.Retired receptionist Eileen Webster, , says “climate change is the big issue facing the next generation”, while Anna Lubecka, , demands new PM Boris Johnson, “start making good plans for climate change”.Attitudes to environmentalism have shted so much that being green is now no longer the preserve of lentil-munching hippies and Swampy, it is totally mainstream.No trendy bar would now dare put plastic straws in their cocktails.We’ve all got used to carrying Love Island-style water bottles and happily adopted reusable coffee cups. This year they pulled off a plastic-free Glastonbury, despite a few hiccups.We’ve long stopped grumbling about taking our own bags to the supermarket and got used to stuffing our pockets with them when we leave the house.So now in England, the average person uses less than a tenth of the number of single-use plastic bags than we did five years ago. Only around ten a year, compared to  in .As electric cars have improved, we’ve all been seduced — and not just by Tesla’s new “bulletproof” Cybertruck. Overall, demand for electric cars has jumped, with the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders finding that this November alone electric car sales leaped by . per cent, with more than three times as many new battery-electric vehicles registered as in the same month in .Nowhere  is it clearer that green has become the new black than in fashion, where criticism of fast fashion has led to trends for vintage, second hand and renting rather than buying.On the high street, companies such as HM have launched their “conscious collection” , fashion bible Vogue has championed sustainable designs, while French President Emmanuel Macron’s “fashion pact” — presented at the G summit and intended to make the industry more sustainable — has been signed by more than  brands, including Nike, Zara and Gap.All these changes prove how far we have come and the impact Greta has had.Hearing her, strong and calm, on Radio ’s Today programme this week, what struck me is that now another change is needed.This time a sht not in our actions, but in how we approach the environmental debate.It’s not beliefs but attitudes that need to change. Until now, environmental issues have been too isive.Butwe want real change we’ve got to move beyond blame.It puts people off environmental issues when campaigners hector and shame them.When wealthy celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough criticise normal people for taking holidays with cheap flights, or actress Emma Thompson jets back from America to harass normal people driving to work.In the same way Extinction Rebellion threatens to lose potential supporters when it starts fights with commuters trying to board their morning train or cause mayhem in central London.The real danger is that by being so aggressive, these green campaigners risk putting people off.Greta seems to know this. She is much calmer than she used to be when speaking in public.Rather than getting angry or emotional, instead she has stressed the importance of just, “listening to the scientists”.As usual, we could learn from her.The reality is most people want to be green.We are all concerned about global warming, pollution in the seas and the kind of planet we are creating for our grandkids. But you can’t shame people into doing something.Diesel drivers — especially White Van Man — shouldn’t be harassed just for getting to work. I’m sure they would buy more environmentally friendly vehiclesthey could afford to.Likewise, no one should be shamed for taking a flight — who knows what other measures they might be taking, such as living in a carbon neutral home What the planet needs least is more fighting. Instead we need grown-up debate.The answer to the climate crisis isn’t to criticise each other — it’s to work together to make real change. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pope francis lashes worshipper arm st peters square
story: The -year-old was on his way to visit a nativity scene in Vatican Citys central plaza when the woman grabbed his hand and yanked him towards her.He had reached over a barrier to touch a child and had already turned to walk away when he was pulled back.The visibly-shocked pontf stumbled slightly as he moved back towards the barrier and appeared to be in some pain.He then scolded the woman verbally before slapping her hand twice when she still refused to let go.Security guards then moved in to pry the woman off him.The woman had made the sign of the cross as the Pope walked towards her, and was trying to talk to him as she held his hand, although it is not clear what she was saying.The Pope has now apologised over the incident, saying he set a bad example to his millions of followers.He was later filmed continuing to shake hands with worshippers and kissing the cheek of a baby passed to his guards by its mother.At the New Years Eve evening service at St Peters Basilica, the Pope told the congregation to practice solidarity and to build bridges, not walls.On Christmas Eve, he said the light of Christmas should be allowed to counter the darkness of human hearts, mentioning in particular unrest in Ukraine, Venezuela, Syria, and a number of countries in Africa.He also called for compassion for migrants forced by conflicts and economic hardship to emigrate in the hope of a secure le.He said that after perilous journeys, they are often find themselves before walls of indference in places where they might have hoped for a dignied le.The New Years incident is not the first time the Pope has rebuffed affection by the faithful.In March, he was filmed repeatedly pulling away his hand as followers made to kiss his ring during a visit to Italys Holy House of Loreto basilica.Vatican spokesman Alessandro Gisotti later explained the footage, saying: The Holy Father told me that the motivation was very simple: hygiene.He wants to avoid the risk of contagion for the people, not for him.

title: york set to be the first uk city to ban all private car journeys in bid to be carbon neutral by 2030
story: In radical new proposals the city council is looking to stop all non essential car journeys taking place within the city walls by .The idea follows the lead taken by Bristol City Council in November which agreed to ban diesel cars from entering the city centre by .York is aiming to become carbon neutral by  -  years sooner than the UKs national target.More than  , people live in and around the city which also attracts millions of tourist each year.Councillors have acknowledged they will not be able to achieve the goal unless they take dficult and ambitious steps.According to York Press Labour councillor Jonny Crawshaw said the ban was not aimed to stop people from visiting the city or to stop residents from owning a car.He said: This is about reducing and removing non-essential car journeys across the whole city, whilst improving the range and attractiveness of alternative travel options.Fewer cars on York’s roads would enable faster, more reliable public transport from the suburbs and villages into the city centre.Fewer cars on the roads would make cycling feel safer and more viable option for more people.The plans were approved by the council who will now look  for a way to implement the ban over the next three years.They will also look to stop more non-essential car journeys on roads at the citys schools at pick-up and drop-off time.Mr Crawshaw added those who rely on car travel such as disabled residents would be exempt from the ban. Buses would also be exempt.

story: From a -year-old inn to an old tobacco merchant, the Good Pub Guide Awards have scoured the UK for the best drinking spots of .The guide handed pubs awards in a range of categories, including best choice of beer or wine, best new pub, and most unspolit.Editor Fiona Stapley said: Since we started the Good Pub Guide nearly  years ago what has not changed is our enjoyment of a well-run pub – they make us happy.They are the hub of a local community where customers of all walks of le and of all ages mix easily and they are run by extraordinary, hard-working licensees who have adapted their establishments to fit in with the needs and whims of our modern lives.They are uniquely British and should be celebrated. title: karen matthews ring engaged handyman
story: She met her handyman fiancé when he did odd jobs at her home and he proposed over Christmas.Matthews, , jailed for faking daughter Shannon’s abduction, has been showing off a ­Princess Diana-style ring after getting engaged.She flashed the sparkler this week as she and her handyman husband-to-be were out shopping.Matthews tried to bluff her way to reward money by helping to stage the abduction of daughter Shannon, then nine.She was jailed for eight years for the warped  stunt in Dewsbury, West Yorks.Matthews met her fiancé, named Paul, after moving to a secret home in the South of England following her release.She has told him who she is but he seems unconcerned by her notorious past.He proposed over Christmas and pals have described them as “inseparable”.The pair are the talk of the town, which cannot be named for legal reasons.They are understood to have met when he was doing repair work at the flat she was given at taxpayers’ expense.A source told The Sun: “She is in love with him. Both of them have been walking round like teenagers.“The ring is like Princess Diana’s design. She apparently bought it herself with money she saved.“He knows who she is but he can’t be bothered about her past. He’s been staying over pretty often.“I just think it’s disgusting that anyone could want to be in a relationship with her.”Shannon was discovered by police under a bed at the home of Michael Donovan — the uncle of her mum’s boyfriend.Matthews and Donovan dreamt up the fake kidnap to try to claim a £, reward for her daughter’s safe .The vile mum was released with a new ID in April  after serving half her sentence.Last year she had complained about her reputation, claiming: “I’m not Britain’s worst mum. I didn’t kill anybody. I’m scared I’ll die lonely and alone.”Her last serious boyfriend, supermarket fishmonger Craig Meehan, shared a house with her in Dewsbury for around five years.He was unaware of her abduction scam with his uncle.But he did get  weeks’ jail after police probing Shannon’s disappearance found child abuse images on his computer.February , : Last confirmed sighting of Shannon outside school.February : Police say more than  officers are searching for her.March : Her mum Karen Matthews issues an emotional appeal.March : The Sun increases its £, reward to £,.March : Shannon found hidden in the base of a an bed at Michael Donovan’s flat.December : Matthews and Donovan, uncle of her boyfriend Craig Meehan, left, found guilty of the vile trick.January , : Matthews and Donovan get eight years each.April : Matthews is freed and changes her name.When The Sun knocked on Matthews’ door to try to talk to her and Paul, he answered in a tracksuit.He initially denied knowing her. But when shown a picture of them together, he raged: “It’s got nothing to do with anybody. I’m not saying nothing. It’s about time the Press kept their noses out of other people’s business.“If you come knocking on this door again I will forcibly remove you. title: hugs clean air holidays gadgets trends 2020
story: The -year-old predicted the clean eating craze, the rise of the snowflake generation and metrosexual men and she was one of the first to warn of the  financial crash.Today we hear what New Yorker Marian – whose Annual Trends report is a bible for companies wanting to know the next big thing – is predicting for , which she believes will be the Year of the Hug.It has never been easier to reach out to friends and colleagues anywhere in the world.But the more digitally connected we all become, the more we risk becoming disconnected emotionally and physically.We each live in our own inidualised, personally curated bubble — and we are feeling the impact.At our core, humans are social animals. We need contact — and not just emotional — but physical.There’s even a psychological term for it, skin hunger.People are responding to this tech-driven disconnect by seeking out physical contact in any way they can.The most obvious example is the rise of hugging.There’s a lot more hugging as a greeting between men than there used to be, even between sporting opponents.And what on earth happened to the stand-offish Brits  Great British Bake Off contestants spend nearly as much time holding hands and wrapping their arms around each other as they do baking.We have become so hungry for touch that we don’t even need a human partner.The odds are that someone you know will have received a weighted blanket for Christmas.It is essentially a duvet cover filled with plastic or glass pellets or beads.Manufacturers say the even pressure they exert on your body promotes the release of well-being chemical serotonin and sleep hormone melatonin, while reducing stress-related hormone cortisol.In plain language we’re talking about feeling the comfort and security of being cradled, evenit’s by a blanket rather than in the arms of a loved one.For those who want to take the experience of being hugged to a whole new level, Otonamaki, the Japanese practice of adult swaddling, will become popular in .After getting into a foetal position, the client is bound tightly in sheets, then gently rocked for  minutes.I ran across a tweet not long ago that read: “My phone just said, ‘Welcome home’, and I instinctively replied, ‘I love you’. Then I realised I meant it.”We may be interacting with our fellow humans less often, but we’re more than making up for it with digital interactions, even to the point of developing feelings for these devices.As our devices get smarter and master the intricacies of natural language processing, we will increasingly see them as confidants, friends and even romantic partners.Already people are interacting with chatbots instead of flesh-and-blood therapists.And we’re seeing all sorts of digital apps promising to improve our mental health, from Moodfit and MoodMission to Happy.As developers figure out how to make our smart devices ever more personable, it doesn’t take a soothsayer to recognise that a global population increasingly suffering from loneliness and disconnectedness will find solutions of a sort in these gadgets.The desire for clean air in cities will not only lead to pricier houses on less polluted streets but tourists will give up city breaks for holidays in the country, where the air is good.As living in places with clean air becomes a luxury with a high price tag, expect new takes on face masks to become a must-have item for people in cities and a race towards rural living.Expect an explosion of products, from vegan leather to plant-based burgers and articial wood.If you buy a vegan burger and cook it at home, you have consumed a burger made with eight times less water and CO than a conventional beef burger.These sorts of products may be described as “fake” but the feelings people get of having made an ethically better choice are very real.Uncertainty begets fear, so look out for a rise in preppers — survivalists preparing for Armageddon.In the US, prepping is mainstream enough for Costco to sell a £, one-year stockpile of survival food for four.Survivalists are at the extreme end of the bunker trend.More mainstream are the millions who aren’t worried enough to go all-out prepper but still view the outside world as a threat.Driven by concerns about personal security and terrorism, CCTV covering public and commercial spaces is becoming a global norm.London is sixth in the world for TV surveillance, the only non-Chinese city in the top eight.And sales of home video surveillance on smartphones, courtesy of Google Nest, Ring and Wyze Cam, are booming.The global market is expected to rise from £billion to £billion by .Expect the self-tracking trend to run and run.For more and more people, there’s something irresistible about gadgets that put statistics to common everyday activities.For things that can’t yet be tracked automatically, they can input data manually — MyMoodTracker for emotions, MyNetDiary for nutrition and PoopLog for toilet visits.Google announced it intended to buy Fitbit for nearly £billion, prompting some to say they will ditch their device out of concern that Google will sell their health data to insurance companies.But rather than wait to buy third-party data, insurance companies are already getting into the game.: Single, professional women will become the new free-spending yuppies.: Publishes a study of the soft modern male, who she described as “metrosexual man”.: Predicts “sleep is the new sex” and “clean eating”. Forecasts the sub-prime crisis that led to the  financial crash.: Identies a new “snowflake” mindset where “everybody wants to save the Earth but no one wants to help Mum with the dishes”.: Identies Daddy bloggers as more fathers bring up kids.: Forecasts the rise of “truthiness” – where facts seem to matter little.: Predicts rise of gender-neutral society. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: northern ireland powersharing talks resume
story: NewsNorthern Ireland powersharing talks resume in bid to restore devolved governmentDevolution can only be restoredthe DUP and Sinn Fein can agree on terms to re-enter a coalition in BelfastShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentDavid Young:,  JAN News " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNorthern Ireland powersharing talks resumed this morning, in a bid to restore devolved government in the region.The latest process, which was initiated in the wake of the general election , was paused over the festive period after a pre-Christmas deal failed to materialise.Three years on from the collapse of the devolved government, the Stormont parties have until a January  deadline to strike a deal to revive the institutions. On that date, legislation to give civil servants additional powers to run Northern Irelandaposs struggling public services expires and Secretary of State Julian Smith will assume a legal obligation to call a snap Assembly election. The latest push to restore powersharing broke up the week before Christmas, with UK and Irish governments singling out the DUP as the party standing in the way of a deal. The party rejected the claims, insisting it would not be bounced into a quick fix that falls apart when tested. Devolution can only be restored once the DUP and Sinn Fein - the regionaposs two largest parties - agree terms to re-enter a mandatory coalition executive in Belfast. The other three main parties - the SDLP, Ulster Unionists and Alliance - are also involved in the talks process convened by the UK and Irish governments. While they could take positions in any new executive, their sign-off on a deal is not essential and a government could be formed in their absence, with those parties having the option of going into opposition. Expectations of a breakthrough rose after the DUP and Sinn Fein both suffered bruising results in the general election. With many interpreting the outcome as a public judgment on the partiesapos failure to do a deal, stalled efforts to restore the institutions appeared to gain fresh momentum in December. However, proposals to reform a contentious cross-community voting mechanism in the Assembly have emerged as a key sticking point in efforts to finalise an agreement, with the DUP unhappy about what is being countenanced. The DUP is also seeking changes to ensure the devolved institutions are more stable in future and cannot be readily pulled down. Proposed legislative protections for Irish language speakers are another crucial element of the negotiations. The Stormont parties are also seeking firm commitments from the UK government on a financial package to accompany theof devolution - money that would likely be targeted at the regionaposs crisis-hit health service.  Irelandaposs deputy premier Simon Coveney and Mr Smith were in Belfast on New Yearaposs Day for pre-talks discussions ahead of the resumption of formal exchanges with the political parties. Mr Coveney urged the parties to show leadership and generosity. He said the new year offered a chance for a new beginning and urged all sides not to disappoint the public again. The leaders of the DUP and Sinn Fein used their respective new year messages to restate a desire toto government. DUP leader Arlene Foster said her party stood ready to restore devolution through a fair and balanced deal. A Northern Ireland that is going to keeping moving forward must be one where everyone feels at home but must also be one where no one feels their culture is being marginalised, she said. While Ms Foster warned that a focus on a potential border poll would lead to a wasted decade, Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald insisted a united Ireland was within reach. But the republican leader added: There is no contradiction in working for Irish unity and working for the restoration of the Executive and Assembly - they are all part of the Good Friday Agreement. The outstanding issues can be resolved. The time for acrimony and ision is over. The time for slogans and soundbites is over. The test now for every party that has talked up getting back to work is to go back to the Executive table and deliver.

title: dundee frustrated but draw shows why utd are so far clear at top
story: I can see James McPake’s frustration that Dundee didn’t win on Friday night but the - draw at Tannadice showed exactly why Dundee United are where they are.The Dark Blues probably were the better team in the end and they’ll take plenty of positives out of it but it was a good result for the Tangerines, too.I agree with manager Robbie Neilson saying his side didn’t play as well as they could have.For some reason, they looked a bit anxious and nervy in the second half which is completely unlike them.United had done so well in the previous derbies and been so assured it was a surprise to see them just lump the ball forward as the game wore on.However, the sign of a title-winning team is they can still take a point despite not playing well against one of the better sides in the ision.And they even extended their lead at the top as, once more, the other sides failed to take advantage of United dropping points.For James and his side, they were far better than previous derby showings, that much is obvious.It was a step forward for them and will give their fans a positive jolt heading into the new year.I still think they have problems creating chances.They had lots of good play in the second half but still can’t convert that into clear-cut opportunities.Look at the stats and, though Dundee about edged the game for me, United still had more shots on goal.I do think the way the Dens gaffer has set up his team recently suits them better and that showed on Friday night.There’s more balance in the midfield with Fin Robertson and Graham Dorrans taking turns to control things in the middle.It’s taken a while, which is understandable given the big changes in the summer, but James is starting to find a good formation and his best starting XI.These things always take time but it seems like the Dee are getting there.The key is they kick on from here.For United, it’s about ticking over and keeping themselves well clear of any trouble at the top.Sounds like there were a fair few interested parties at the derby, no doubt taking a look at Lawrence Shankland after his goalscoring exploits this season.It wouldn’t surprise methose English clubs were keeping an eye on Robertson and Dorrans either, the way those two are performing.

title: dundee united 1 1 dundee dorrans first goal earns dee derby point
story: Graham Dorrans# first goal for Dundee earned his side a point as they came from behind at Tannadice to end Dundee United#s derby dominance.Nicky Clark had given league leaders United an early advantage but Dorrans rled home the equaliser in the second period to end the Terrors# nine-game winning streak and perfect derby record this season.Dundee were unchanged from their win over Partick last weekend while Louis Appere replaced the injured Sam Stanton for United.And it was the Tangerines who got off to a dream start in front of a , near-sell-out, scoring with the first attack and shot of the game after just five minutes.Appere released Jamie Robson on the overlap down the left and the full-back#s delivery was flicked home by Clark for his seventh goal of the season.Action threatened to boil over on  minutes as Robson and Dundee#s Paul McGowan exchanged handbags in the corner but referee Alan Muir kept his cards in his pocket.And it was McGowan who had the Dark Blues# first real chance of the game on  minutes.The -year-old picked up on a Jordan Marshall cut back, twisted and turned in the box to make some space but saw his shot deflected behind for a corner.On  minutes McGowan was again denied by Siegrist inside the box as he collected a lovely reverse pass from -year-old Fin Robertson but couldn#t find a way past the big Swiss.Terrors talisman Lawrence Shankland had his first clear-cut chance of the game  minutes before half-time but couldn#t head home from six yards out after Robson#s delivery.Calum Butcher escaped a booking on two counts as he went in heavy on Danny Johnson and McGowan as tempers began to flare as the game approached half-time.Dee keeper Jack Hamilton did well to deny Ian Harkes from close range to keep the score down at the interval.Much like the opening period, there was an early goal to start the second half # and it was Dundee who got it.Five minutes after the action restarted Dorrans got on the end of Liam Smith#s clearance to rle home a left-footed volley for his first goal for the club.With the match level, the Dark Blues almost took the lead moments later as Johnson was inches away from getting on the end of a Sean Mackie cross.On  minutes, Shankland went close as he nodded Paul McMullan#s cross just wide of Hamilton#s left-hand post as both teams pushed for a winner.However, both sides had to settle for a point apiece as they go into the new year United sitting top and Dundee in play-off contention.Dundee United XI : SiegristL Smith, Watson, Reynolds , Robson Butcher, Harkes, McMullan, Clark , Appere Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Connolly, C Smith, Chalmers, King and Mochrie.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, McGhee, Meekings , Marshall McGowan, Robertson, Dorrans, Mackie Hemmings, Johnson .Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Todd, Byrne, Moore and Mulligan.Ref: Alan Muir.Att: , .

story: Dundee United manager Robbie Neilson expects there to be interest in his star players when the January transfer window opens at midnight.Scouts from ious clubs, including Queens Park Rangers, Norwich City, Brentford, Everton and Rangers, were in attendance at Tannadice for last Friday’s - with his name selected hundreds of times more than nearest rival Max Lowe.CENTRAL-MIDFIELD TWO: Our pundits, Dons icons Joe Harper and Willie Miller, and Scotland women’s captain Rachel Corsie, only title: thank god we had niall to give us some quality says mcinnes
story: Boss Derek McInnes today praised Niall McGinn for battling through injury to net an equaliser at Tynecastle.McInnes confirmed the winger had been struggling with a muscle problem and only passed a late fitness test on the morning of the Premiership clash at Hearts.Pittodrie physios deemed the Northern Ireland winger was not fit enough to play for an entire  minutes.McInnes opted to name McGinn on the bench in the hope he could be introduced as an impact substitute.McGinn was brought on late in the first half as a replacement for Zak Vyner.On-loan Bristol City defender Vyner suffered a shoulder injury.Vyner will be assessed by a specialist and McInnes fears surgery may be required which could end the -year-old’s season.McGinn salvaged a - draw for the Reds against the Premiership’s bottom side with a superb free-kick.McInnes said: “Niall has been struggling with injury for the last few weeks.“He has had a little calf, hamstring thing.“It is a nerve thing that has affected his training.“Niall passed a fitness test on the day of the game but the phyisos said he didn’t have  minutes in him. He played  minutes against Livingstonwhen we only planned to play Niall for  minutes.“Niall did not have  minutes in him against Hearts but thank God we had him to call upon.“He has been doing that for years for us now, turning up when the game is screaming for a bit of quality. When we were screaming out for that quality, calmness and decision making Niall was there, as he normally is.”McGinn’s superb -yard free kick came immediately after Hearts had been reduced to  men.Sean Clare received a straight red for pulling back Jon Gallagher as the on-loan Atlanta United attacker broke in on goal.McGinn’s equaliser was the only moment of real attacking quality from Aberdeen. McInnes started with two strikers, Bruce Anderson and Curtis Main.McInnes said: “At half time we spoke with a bit of honesty about how we were not passing the ball well enough or showing enough of ourselves.“We were better when we went back to a more familiar shape with one up when Bruce went up on his own.“In the last  minutes of the game we were devoid of quality, calmness and the right decision making.“We all became a bit too rushed in what we were doing in sailing it forward and not moving the ball quick enough at times.“It was in these moments that we had to show a bit more experience, control and composure to get to their goal and get a winner.“Unfortunately we didn’t do enough to do that.”

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

title: 39-year-old-knocked-partners-windows-three-hours
story: A -year-old man was thrown out of his partners home but repeatedly knocked on the door and windows for three hours before police were called.Blair Scott pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the domestic-related offence at a house in Kenilworth Avenue, Galashiels, on November .Kate Irwin, prosecuting, said: "The couple had been in a relationship for about a year. The complainer asked him to leave because she believed he had been involved in drugs."He went away but ed at .pm and was repeatedly striking the windows and doors wanting to get back in."This happened for the next three hours before the complainer eventually phoned the police."Sentence was deferred on Scott - now residing in Edinburgh - until January  to establishthere was any reason why a Non-Harassment Order should not be imposed in this case.

title: happiness-borders-comes-dalai-lamas-blessing
story: THE Dalai Lama has given his blessing to a new course being run in the Borders which promises to make people happier and the world a better place.The eight-week course is designed by the Action for Happiness organisation - a UK based movement with over , members which takes action for a happier world.Entitled Exploring What Matters, the weekly courses will be offered in Peebles and Innerleithen in the New Year.It is a secular project based on science rather than faith and is open to people of all backgrounds.The course is backed by the Dalai Lama, who said: ldquoAs patron of Action for Happiness I am delighted to see the work being done by members of this movement to create a happier and more caring society."I wholeheartedly support the Exploring What Matters course and hope that many thousands of people will benefit from it and be inspired to take their own action to help create a happier world.Analysis of the course has found that it leaves people both happier and more pro-social, with participants reporting increases in levels of le satisfaction, mental wellbeing, compassion and social trust.Many say the course is le-changing.In Exploring What Matters, local groups meet for eight weeks, with each session exploring a big question.They start with "What really matters in le " and then "What really makes us happy ".These are followed by sessions on dealing with adversity, having good relationships, caring for others, and creating happier workplaces and communities.They end with "How can we create a happier world The first eight week course is being run in Peebles on a voluntary basis by Suzi Gibson and Laura Swan in Space, Greenside every Thursday starting on January .Suzi said: ldquoIrsquom very excited to be running this course because happier iniduals make for a happier community and I am passionate about bringing people together to discuss what matters. I canrsquot think of a better use of my time than helping myself and others be happier.The Innerleithen-based course is being run by Lois Hindley and Cath Shepheard and takes place at Innerleithen Church of Scotland every Wednesday starting on January .And whatrsquos even better is the cost of happiness is free, but the organisers do ask for a small donation to cover costs.If you would like to search for happiness contact Laura Swan at hello@lauraswan
