title: Addams Family production is huge success
story: ST Patrickrsquos Grammar School students once again enjoyed a phenomenally successful run in their recent production of The Addams Family.Under the direction of Siobhan OrsquoToole, Head of Drama, the performers received standing ovations after each show, which according an audience member would not have out of place in the West End of London.Pupils from every year group in the school were involved in the production and assumed major roles of responsibility, ranging from stage managers to set design.From start to finish, the show was pacy and slick, bursting with comedy and superb aesthetics. The principal cast performed like seasoned professionals, bringing the iconic characters to le with flair and panache.Eoin McGuinness and Ellen McGurnaghan were outstanding in their comic portrayals of Gomez and Morticia Addams, while Annie Haughey and Eoin Moore were superb as the sinister siblings, Wednesday and Pugsley.The hilariously embarrassing grandmother was played by Aisha Oladipupo, and Year  student Conaire Laverty brought endless laughs as the grunting Lurch. Conn Murnin, as Uncle Fester, was a particular audience favourite and his departure on a rocket to seek the love of his le mdash the Moon mdash was a highlight of the show.The ever present long dead Addams ancestors were a tight and focused chorus including a stunning range of costumes from cavemen to flappers. All-American family, the Beinekes, played by Malachy McGrady, Elisha Tumelty and Tomaacutes Harkinleft the audience in stitches as they struggled to deal with ways of the weird and wonderful Addams family. All ended happily ever after, however, as both families moved towards the darkness and embraced who they really were.Featuring an exceptional live orchestra led by Head of Music Celeste McEvoy and music teacher Ciara Coleman, and with magnicent set, costume, lighting and sound complementing the breathtaking musical and dramatic talent of these students, it really was a show not to be missed..prettyPhoto

title: Boyle family celebrates as Tom marks milestone 100th birthday
story: A DOWNPATRICK man celebrated his th birthday before Christmas.Tom Boyle, the townrsquos former postmaster, became a centenarian on December .He was congratulated by a steady stream of relatives and well-wishers who called to the home he shares with we Maria in a low-key celebration.He is third local man to celebrate his centenary during .Felix Burns, from Rossglass, turned the big  in May, and was followed in August by Roddy Maguire from Downpatrick.All three received congratulatory card from the Queen. As the men were all born citizens of Ireland, they each also received a letter and euro, cheque from Irish President Michael D Higgins mdash a special financial bounty given by the Irish State known as the Centenarian award.Born in Warrenpoint before moving to Omeath and onwards to Belfast, Mr Boyle came to Downpatrick as postmaster in .According to his we, he can boast of having retired on two occasions, first from Downpatrick Post Office when he was in his s and again when he was in his s, as he helped Mrs Boyle out in her role as sub post office mistress in Strangford.When asked what he ascribed his long le to, quick as a flash, he answered: ldquoBreathing.He added: ldquoI canrsquot really explain how I managed to get to this age as Irsquove done nothing special. I just take one day at a time and then the next day. They seem to add up and then you are .Mr Boyle is the last of his family of three brothers and two sisters. He followed his fatherrsquos footsteps in working for the Post Office.He and his we have been married for  years and while they have spent over  years living in Downpatrick, they lived for around  years in Killough, which they remember as a particularly happy time.Parents to five children mdash Desmond, Ciaran, Damian, Philip and Roisin mdash the couple have eight grandchildren mdash Emma, Maria, Madeline, Ciara, Enya, Meabh, Grace and Thomas..prettyPhoto

title: Christmas cracker in store
story: KILLOUGH have every intention on rockinrsquo around the Christmas tree with the Bobby Dalzell Cup next Thursday night.Standing in the way of the Mill Field sidersquos celebrations are Ballynahinch Olympic Town, who also want their hands on the coveted trophy.The Yuletide showdown at Meadowvale is sure to be a Christmas cracker.Both sides know only one way to play and that is attack, attack, attack.Between them they scored  goals in the semi-finals and more are promised on Boxing Day.Killough, cup specialists over the past  years or so, know how to win big games.They have a cup mentality and leave nothing out on the pitch, reserving their best form for one-off encounters.In Colm Stranney at centre half they have a freak of nature.The guy is still going strongly at  years of age and he will be playing in his th final for the club mdash winning six and losing four.He is the glue that keeps Killough bonded together.Sound in the air, deceptively quick on the ground and absolutely fearless in the tackle, Stranney really is a man for all seasons.He is the sort of player who gets on with the job without histrionics or fuss and he even has time to nurture young talent when they break into the first team squad.He certainly has his hands full this season as Killough have introduced teenage brothers Sean Ogand Riain Burnsinto the  to join  year-old Ben McLaughlin, younger brother of winger, Jack.Sean Og has knitted in perfectly at the back alongside Stranney and they will probably be joined by Matthew Burns, Ben McLaughlin or Seamas Tumelty.Goalkeeper Eddie Hinc has already repaid the faith the club has shown in him and he is the perfect replacement for Chris Mallon, who continues to play for the clubrsquos second string.Killough are also spoiled for choice when it comes to their midfield unit.Matt McKiernan will be asked to fill the holding rolehe has recovered from injury, a job he does with consummate easeJust in front of him come the clubrsquos Holy Trinity in skipper Gareth George, Tony McIlhone and Adam George, who is not ing to the USA until the end of the month.Killough play this trio as a central raiding party.They close the opposition down with relish and intensity and force opponents into giving the ball away.However, it will be dficult playing this style on the big pitch at Meadowvale and Killough just might well adopt a new formation.Former Cltonville and Downpatrick FC winger Jack McLaughlin, who missed the semi-final win over Ballynagross due to illness, should start in a wide role leaving Ross Armstrong to play up front on his own.Armstrong is like Stranney, a dedicated, under-rated servant who gives his all and then some more, every time he pulls on a Killough shirtManager John Fitzsimmons, who has never lost a cup final with Killough, feels his side are running into some nice from at the minute and canrsquot wait to get going.ldquoWersquoll let the boys enjoy Christmas day with their families and then get them into the right frame of mind on Boxing Day, he enthused.ldquoWe are going well at the minute and looking forward to the final. The boys are all training hard and we are working on a few dferent permutations for the decider, but it will definitely be horses for courses.ldquoTony McIlhone, Jack McLaughlin and Adam and Gareth George will be key for us in the final. Their experience should stand us in good stead, but I have absolutely no doubt that our young players will rise to the occasion, he added.Fitzsimmons paid tribute to Gerard Kelly, who led the team, to Harry Clarke Cup success last season with Kieran Sharvin and who is still in the management team.ldquoIt is a pleasure and honour to work alongside Gerard, who puts so much effort into keeping the club going. We have been friends for many years and work so well together, he said.ldquoWe have come up with a few ideas on how to get at Ballynahinch Olympic, but we will leave that information to the changing rooms in Meadowvale.Barry McGoran and Marty Sloan have moulded Ballynahinch Olympic Town into a force to be reckoned with, despite the fact that they rarely field with the same  every week due to first team call-ups.As a reserve team, people tend to write them off in the big games, but theyrsquove consistently proved that theyrsquore good enough to compete with anyone.The squad has done exceptionally well to get to another final, but they wont be happy until they get our hands on the cup.McGoran and Sloan like to play the same way as Killough and use the tactic of attack being the best means of defence and Barry feels that Olympic arenrsquot far away from lting the trophy.ldquoWersquore only half way there and need to stay focused. We got a bit carried away last year, but wersquove learnt from that. We need calm heads now, hesaid.ldquoKillough will go into the final as favourites. Theyrsquore a good side with some quality players, especially in midfield and can be lethal going forward, but so can we. We showed that in the semi-final and we have plenty of quality players ourselves.In lsquokeeper John McMenamin Olympic have an experienced custodian, who is a great shot-stopper and as brave as they come.A mixture of Niall McGlew, Mick Rice, Gavin McMullan, Thomas Rodgers Reece McConnell, Darryl Russell and Liam Sloan will make up a formidable defensive barrier with Simon Marmion handed the playmakerrsquos role in the middle of midfield.Shane Rodgers, Simon Marmion, Jack Roddy, Josh Fennell, Gary Wilson, Daniel Rice, Stephen King, Dylan McCartan and Connor Reid will vie for starting places alongside Marmion leaving the twin threat of Darren Lyons and Aaron McCaffrey up front.This pair compliment one and other perfectly.Both are comfortable on the ball and both are workaholics. Defenders canrsquot take an eye off either one as they will destroy you in a flash.McGoran believes his side are ready to cash in on the success of the clubrsquos first team.ldquo The club has come a long way in recent years and when you see the success that our first team is having its incredible, McGoran beamed.ldquoThe professionalism and dedication they show in training has filtered down through the club and it has inspired the younger players to put the work in to try and get to that level mdash and thatrsquos a big part of why our seconds team is doing so well.ldquoLast year ended up being a disappointing Christmas for the club, so itrsquos up to us all to make sure we put things right this time around..prettyPhoto

title: Devaney elected as new chairman of Down GAA
story: DOWN GAA elected a new chairman at the annual convention in Newry last Wednesday evening. Bredaghrsquos John Devaney becomes the st holder of the countyrsquos main position, having been selected unopposed to succeed Mayobridge man Sean Rooney.In his first address to delegates, Mr Devaney outlined a strategic vision for the association in the county and a number of areas of focus for his term of office.The key priorities will be the proposed Centre of Excellence, the development of a new coaching plan, recruitment of referees, and a programme to encourage and nurture new and young administrators.Following his election, Devaney said: ldquoThe Ballykinlar Centre of Excellence is clearly the single biggest project that we will have undertaken, and will take time and resource to bring to fruition. ldquoWe have set out our intention and we are determined that it will happen, because it is a fantastic opportunity for the county. But it is only the only project.ldquoThere is quite a lot we can achieve in other areas, on and off the fields of play. Coaching, refereeing, administration, club development and fundraising will also require our attention, he added.ldquoAnd we also want to have the ambition for our teams to reach their potential and challenge for honours. So, the future has real potential for us, but it will require a lot of support, goodwill and a unity of purpose across the county. A native of Killoe in Co Longford, Devaney has been an officer with Down GAA since . He is a former chairman of the Queenrsquos University GAA club and the Higher Education GAA Council, and has served on Ulster Council Management Committee and Central Council.Further details on the proposed new Centre of Excellence at Ballykinlar were outlined at Wednesdayrsquos meeting.Planning permission for the development was submitted earlier last week and the early concept designs of the complex were presented to club delegates. The site at the Ministry of Defence base will encompass four pitches, a MUGA and an administration and exhibition museum centre. Down GAA will now plan to appoint a Project Board in the New Year.Maureen OrsquoHigginswas elected as the new vice-chairperson of the board, on an evening when a number of officerships changed hands.Outgoing chairman Sean Rooney was selected to represent the county on the Ulster Council alongside Sean McCashin. Donal McNallywill assume the position of Irish and Cultural Officer, while Drumgathrsquos Michael McArdle is the new delegate to Central Council.As a result of disciplined financial management in recent years, the presentation of the financial report by treasurer Diarmuid Cahill showed a strong position for the county moving forward.Fourteen motions on the convention agenda were all approved, including ten proposals to go forward to the GAA Congress in Dublin at the end of February. These include: points deduction as a penalty option for a breach of the rule on lsquomisconduct considered to have discredited the association removing the rule which allows a newly-transferred player to finish playing in a competition he had started with his former club a  month hiatus on a further transfer for a player after his transfer has been granted adult inter-club championship games to be extended to  minutes per half.Convention also approved a proposal for the GAA to engage with RTEacute on extending their TV competition provisions to allow entry from viewers in Northern Ireland.Officers elected at the  annual convention: chairman, John Devaneyvice-chairperson, Maureen OrsquoHigginssecretary: Seaacuten Oacuteg McAteer treasurer, Diarmuid Cahillassistant secretary, Michael OrsquoRourkeassistant treasurer, Brendan FitzpatrickPRO, Fiona MurphyDevelopment Officer, Willie GribbenIrish and Culture Officer, Donal McNallyCentral Council delegate, Michael McArdleUlster Council delegates, Sean Rooneyand Sean McCashin ..prettyPhoto

title: Down GAA lodge planning application for £7m centre
story: A FORMAL planning application has been lodged to develop a major new poundm GAA sports centre in Ballykinlar.Details of the ambitious multi-million pound proposal were outlined last November with the proposal including four floodlit pitches. including the current pitch owned by Ballykinlar GAC.The major investment proposal also features changing facilities for players and officials and a multi-use sports area.Other key features of the development mdash which will be financed via a cocktail of funding mdash include spectator seating for , fans at one of the new pitches which it is hoped will in future host club championship games.Plans have also been unveiled for a fitness studio and floodlit walking trail around the new development covering just over  acres of land.The proposed development is also set to become the new administrative base for Down GAA in the county with access to the highly ambitious proposals via Ballykinlar GACrsquos Commons Road base.Described as a major ldquogame changer for football, hurling and camogie at county level, it is also hoped that the new facility located in a stunning location will provide a catalyst for additional investment in Ballykinlar village, helping boost its social and economic regeneration.A number of detailed reports required by planners have already been carried out ahead of the formal planning application lodged shortly before Christmas. It is hoped that construction work can get underway next year.Senior GAA officials have been in discussions with the Ministry of Defence to secure  acres of land to help pave the way for the new development which will be used by all Gaelic games codes in Down.The proposed development is being described as a ldquomassive boost for gaelic games in the area and a key part of a new vision for the sport in Down. It is also hoped that it will provide a signicant resource for the Ballykinlar club and local communities.Down GAA officials say the Ballykinlar project forms part of a new vision for the county and hope that it will lead to success on the field.Former county chairman Sean Rooney, who recently stepped from from his post, said that it will be a ldquophenomenal achievement to deliver the exciting new development.He said the new centre will provide Down GAA with a dedicated, permanent base which is does not have at present, explaining that for many years, the county board has been hiring ious facilities, highlighting the importance of preparing teams for major competitions properly.GAA officials hope that the new centre of excellence will provide a  for future success at county level for footballers, hurlers and camogs.Ballykinlar has been described as the ldquoideal venue as training and matches can take place virtually every day of the year due to excellent ground conditions, with GAA officials excited by the proposals for the future.Ahead of the formal planning application being lodged by the Resolve Planning and Development Innovation Factory, extensive work was carried out, with GAA officials grateful for the support of the Ministry of Defence in advancing the project.The planning application will be scrutinised by Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick couple enjoy 65 years of marital bliss
story: A DOWNPATRICK couple whose introduction was gently engineered by the husband-to-bersquos mother will celebrate  years of marriage on Saturday.Muriel and Alan Major will be surrounded by family and friends when they mark their blue sapphire anniversary.Muriel and Alan, who are both  and from Saul Road, admit they found a ldquogem in each other.They credit their long and happy marriage to a shared love of musicand the arts and never allowing a disagreement to remain too long without making up.The couple say that they have been blessed with three sons, Glenn, Richard and Ian, two grandchildren, Hannah and Thomas, and two great-children, Louis and Lila.They were married at the age of  in Ballyphilip Parish Church, Portaferry, by the Rev Lindsay on December ,. Like many other couples of that era, the wedding was a small affair and they spent a welcome few days honeymooning in Dublin.Alan worked as a writer in the Supply and Secretariat branch of the Royal Navy and soon needed to leave his new bride at home toto his posting. Muriel worked in the office of the now defunct Ulster Transport company.They met on a bus from Belfast to Portaferry and the rest, as they say, is history.ldquoI think we were both on the bus from Belfast and my mother, who knew Muriel, sat beside her and they began to talk and then we were introduced, said Alan. ldquoI was sitting behind and my mother then invited her down for supper the next night.Muriel interjected jokingly: ldquoI was supposed to be going to a shorthand class, which would have made my dear father much happier, but I mitched off and went to the Ritz pictures instead.ldquoHis mother had already spotted me and approved me as a likely candidate for her son as she believed that I knew how to keep house since I was doing it at home as my mother died when I was very young.Alan said that his motherrsquos approval of Muriel very much matched his own.ldquoI had clapped eyes on her before and I thought she will do very nicely for me. It was a private thought, but my mother must have picked up on it and had some insight, he added.Muriel did come for supper the next night and an invitation to a dance was given by Alan. They courted for over a year and more whenever he was home on leave.Alanrsquos parents, Rachel and Ian, were in the next room when Alan later asked Muriel to marry him and they celebrated with tea and supper again.ldquoI was completely flabbergasted but I would say that it was a romantic proposal, recalled Muriel. ldquoAlanrsquos father was great at tending to an open fire in the sitting room and his mother was a great hostess in making scones and cake for supper, so I think just after his father tended the fire, Alan turned tome and asked me to marry me. I think I said yes with a laugh as it was so unexpected.The couple spent the early years of their marriage in Malta where Alan was stationed and where the eldest two sons where born.While the family spent a short time living in Bangor, they have spent the last  years living Downpatrick where Alan went on to work for Radio Rentals in the town, and later in the British Red Cross Society in Belfast, while Muriel worked for the Saul playgroup and later in Downpatrick Library.The couplersquos love of music and going to the theatre, both in Belfast, and at the former Theatre Upstairs, in Irish Street, Downpatrick, was a shared passion over the years.Even today, they both love to watch or listen to concerts on the radio or TV, with performances perking up them up from a trying day or calling on their Alexa to play some Glen Miller music.Muriel said: ldquoWe both love the theatre and we both absolutely love music of all sorts. If therersquos anything that doesnrsquot suit us, we have a wee word with Alexa and say itrsquos your turn to chose.Alan added: ldquoIrsquove often said isnrsquot it wonderful that we have the same tastes in common and thatrsquos a great start to a marriage as well as a good sense of humour and a short memory.Muriel said: ldquoI think it did help that we did like the same things but I would say donrsquot leave it too long before you say sorry for whatever may have happened or been said between you. Itrsquos best done before the night is out.ldquoAlso, I say that having a bit of good manners helps, to say thank you and to appreciate what we do for each other..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick man in roll of honour
story: FORMER Downpatrick and Ireland cricket captain Alfie Linehan was included in a prestigious roll of honour of international sports personalities who died during .He was among  from around the world listed as lsquospecial peoplersquo in BBC Televisionrsquos Sports Personality of the Year programme broadcast at the weekend.They included England goalkeeper Gordon Banks and racing driver Niki Lauda as well as another cricketer mdash one of Englandrsquos greatest fast bowlers, Bob Willis.Alfie died in June after suffering dementia and contracting cancer. He was .He helped take Downpatrick to five senior league and three cup titles and, as a free scoring batsman, captained Ireland in the s. He was also a leading administrator at local and national level.ldquoIt was a lovely surprise for Alfie to be honoured in this way, said his widow, Mary, at her home at Ardmeen outside Downpatrick.ldquoI was on the phone when the item came on and thought I caught Alfiersquos picture. When I wound it back, indeed it was Alfie. I was so surprised, but really pleased.Cricket was to the forefront throughout the programme. England all rounder Ben Stokes won the top inidual award and World Cup winners England took the international team award, collected by Dublin-born captain Eoin Morgan..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum senior citizens get into festive spirit at Christmas dinner
story: SENIOR citizens in Dundrum enjoyed their annual Christmas dinner on Saturday.Staff and helpers at the Dundrum Inn treated over  pensioners to a sumptuous dinner with all the trimmings and also ensured their glasses were filled to the brim.Local man Wilfie Swain extended his gratitude to everyone who helped make the occasion possible.He paid particular thanks to the Dundrum Development Association who sponsored the event, Paddy Cunningham of Dundrum Flowers, who supplied Santa gts, and Francie Cunningham who kept the party swinging with his excellent music and vocals.Thanks were also extended to the Dundrum Inn, the kitchen staff and waiters for their hard work and keeping everything running smoothly.He added: ldquoThanks also to Santa, who, although is very busy this time of year, made a surprise visit to the event with a gt in hand for everyone..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C December 18%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash The opening date for Downpatrickrsquos new swimming pool still remains unknown, but it now seems unlikely that it will be ready for public use before next summer.At the moment that shock prediction suits local councillors who are not yet prepared for an early finish to the work. If the pool is completed soon it would probably lie idle because pool staff have not yet been appointed.The situation has left councillors with red faces for the second time in several months. They have been pushing relentlessly for early completion, but have made no preparations to coincide with a possible quick finish.Last month they demanded a showdown with the poolrsquos architects and had even threatened to invoke penalty clauses on the contractthe pool was not finished soon. They were due to meet the architects this week, but instead were sent a written report on the progress being made.The council clerk, Mr Seamus Byrne, read the report at a council meeting on Monday and said he expected a completion date early in the new year. In the report the architects catalogued a series of setbacks over the past two years and blamed most of the delay on strikes and shortages of materials.Downpatrick councillor, Mr Sean Quinn, launched into a scathing attack on the architects, who, he said, had failed to serve the council as they as they should.Mr Quinn said he found it disturbing that the architects must have known of the troubles on the site, yet had still made ldquowild predictions about the proposed opening date.Mr Quinn also condemned the mounting costs of work on the scheme and then drew attention to the pool itself, saying he felt the interior design was lacking in imagination.Mr Cecil Maxwell reminded councillors that they had approved the pool design and he did not think the architects were at fault for the slow progress.DROMARA mdash ADromara schoolgirl flies out to London tomorrow to represent Northern Ireland in a major essay competition. Sixteen year-old Christine Moore, a pupil at St Colmanrsquos High School in Ballynahinch, is one of  finalists from across the UK in the Sundayessay competition.She has already impressed the judges with her entry on the theme of energy conservation, its economic importance and effect upon western Europe during the next decade.Christine, a sixth form student, could find herself among a shortlist of six finalists after interviews with the City Editor of the Sundayand the senior vice-president of the First National Bank of Chicago.The finalists will be entertained to lunch at the Inn on the Park Hotel, London. The Energy Minister, Mr David Howell, will present a pound cheque to the winner.Christine is the daughter of Mr and Mrs W Moore,  Artana Road, Dromara. She is at present studying for two A Levels in Economics and Accounts.NEWCASTLE mdash Plans to turn Newcastlersquos Percy French Festival into a fully fledged festival of international standing were revealed this week mdash and the Northern Ireland Tourist Board has promised to throw its weight behind it.Already an annual Percy French festival week is held in the town, but now the Tourist Board has come up with an offer of substantial grant aid over the next three years to make it even bigger and better.Plans for the festival were outlined at a meeting of the Heart of Down Accommodation Association in Newcastle with tourist officials and Down District Council. A special festival steering committee has been formed, including representatives of the three bodies.A spokesman for the Tourist Board said: ldquoThe poems, paintings, anecdotes and songs of Percy French, topped, of course, by The Mountains of Mourne, form a magnicent treasure house of tourist material.ldquoWe have no doubt thatthis product is carefully packaged and projected to the world at large, Newcastle in the years to come could have a wonderfully successful festival.ldquoNot only would members of the public enjoy the entertainment, but we believe that many international stars of present day music hall and cabaret would wish to join in celebrating the memory of this talented troubadour.SAINTFIELD mdash The headmaster of Saintfield High School, Mr Ronnie MacPherson, has urged education chiefs to give financial incentives to school teachers.Mr MacPherson was speaking at his schoolrsquos annual prize distribution on Monday night and he also called on teachersrsquo unions to play a more positive role in education.In a hard-hitting speech he told his audience that the morale of the teaching profession was as low as it has probably ever been.ldquoThe public at large have no idea of how serious the situation is in educational institutions and no lessons seem to have been learned by the open signs of unrest seen this year, he said.Mr MacPherson stressed that the importance of schools could not be underestimated. ldquoNext to home the school is the most crucial place for the moral, mental and physical development of citizens. A solution must be found to raise the morale of teachers, he remarked.ldquoWhy is it that teachers today are changing their chosen profession, or taking a second job to supplement their incomes. Teachersrsquo unions will fail the professionthey continue trying to score points off each other and do not unite in seeking wise solutions to the present problems.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh Parish Scouts won the district challenge shield held in the townrsquos high school on Friday night.They had to beat off a strong challenge from the st Downpatrick troop and the outcome of the competition was not decided until the last game, with more than  boys taking part.The district commissioner, Mr Harry Galbraith, handed over to the shield to Stephen Patterson on behalf of the winning troop.The evening was organised by Robert Sharpe, assistant scout leader with Downpatrick, assisted by Glenn Houston, assistant scout leader at Killyleagh.It was a double night of celebration for the Killyleagh troop because they were also awarded the coveted Scout achievement award.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A pound, cheque, the proceeds of a mammoth bring and buy sale in Ballynahinch, was handed over to Oxfam this week and will be used to buy medical supplies and foodstuffs for the Kampuchean refugees.The cheque was handed over by the Rev James Lamont to Annie Hamilton, assistant regional secretary of Oxfam, on behalf of the organisers of the sale which was held in Magheradroll Parish Church Hall last month.This was a tremendous effort in such a short time by the organising committee and townspeople, and thanks must go to Mrs Olive Mateer, committed chairman, Mrs Malachy McCauley and Miss Colette Bonner, secretary, the committee members, the public who helped support the venture, the Rev C W M Cooper and select vestry of Magheradroll Parish Church and the Rev Lamont and members of st Ballynahinch Presbyterian Church for their help.ARDGLASS mdash Councillor Dermot Curran has won the fight to get priority for the development of playing fields in Ardglass. This week Down councillors agreed to move Ardglass to the top of a list of work to be supplied to Enterprise Ulster.Last month the councilrsquos recreation committee had drawn up a priority list with the Ardglass scheme lying second to work on the Plank Drain in Downpatrick. Mr Curran reminded councillors that the Ardglass scheme had been shelved for far too long and he asked for the list to be revised.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Police in Castlewellan have received a number of complaints about dogs roaming in the Bunkers Hill and St Malachyrsquos area of the town. The complaints have been coming from local residents, particularly older people, and police are appealing to dog owners to keep their animals under control..prettyPhoto

title: Kind Rory’s  Christmas collection
story: A KIND-HEARTED Kilclief boy has been responding to a local radio stationrsquos Christmas appeal in a big way.Eight year-old Rory Lenaghan has collected over  gts for babies and teenagers across Northern Ireland who would have very little gts to unwrap this Christmasit was not for him and the generosity of the local people.This is the fth year the P pupil, who attends St Malachyrsquos Primary School in Kilclief, has called on local people to donate toward Mission Christmas Appeal on Cool FM.His mother, Oonagh, says Rory has a huge heart for someone so small and gets very happy when he sees all the gts arrive for the children.She said: ldquoDocrsquos Fish and Chips in Downpatrick, Ardglass and Newcastle offered to be collection points for Roryrsquos appeal. They set up boxes for people to place their gts which has made it very accessible indeed.ldquoIrsquom always amazed at the generosity of the Co Down people. The big demand recently is for babies and teenagers and people donate new gts of make-up sets, hat and glove sets and toddlerrsquos toys, which we gratefully appreciate.ldquoEvery year we see people who are on benefits and donrsquot have much themselves donate the biggest bags. We are always very humbled by it.Rory, who has donated over  gts since he began collecting almost five years ago, is helped by his little two year-old sister, Fianna, and his cousins.Oonagh says sometimes people deliver presents for the appeal to their front door and Fianna begins to jump up and down with excitement, because she thinks they might be for her.ldquoRory, however takes great delight in being able to help other children who are less fortunate than himself. He tells me all the time thateveryone did a collection like this poverty would not exist and people would have enough.ldquoWe donrsquot know peoplersquos financial situation. I tell my children that Santa has to be paid for all the gts he delivers on Christmas Eve. I think itrsquos important children learn that money doesnrsquot grow on trees and that way they learn the value of it.ldquoWhen Rory celebrated his third birthday we had a party for him at the Ballymote Centre. Instead of presents, Rory wanted people to donate toward the childrenrsquos charity NSPCC.ldquoHe raised almost pound and the delight he took in knowing children just like him would feel happier as a result of this, was something .Oonagh says she is always amazed when she meets people who tell her they donrsquot trust charities.She said: ldquoMy response to them is always the same. We canrsquot adopt that attitude because together we can do an awful lot. When I was growing up I watched my own mother and father be very charitable to local causes and I think it has rubbed off on all of us.ldquoSometimes we watch as little Rory would give you the the shirt of his backhe thought you might need it and we think he is an example to all of us.Oonagh wishes to thank everyone who has donated gts to this yearrsquos appeal, as well as Caroline and Morgan Morrisson from Docrsquos Fish and Chips and Ardglass GAC for kindly helping to promote Roryrsquos appeal..prettyPhoto

title: Loggerhead turtle making waves back to full health
story: JC, the little loggerhead turtle currently being rehabilitated at Exploris Aquarium in Portaferry, has taken his next step to being released back into the wild.Following a year of specialised care since being found washed up on a Co Donegal beach last January, JC was recently moved into the ocean tank at Exploris, which will provide him with a more stimulating environment.It will also give him a lot more room to swim and drive around with other animals as well as competing for food mdash all essential to ensure that he has a successful introduction back into the sea.The current inhabitants of the ocean tank at Exploris Aquarium include black reef tip sharks, trigger fish, stingrays along with a iety of large marine reef fish.The turtle made a surprise appearance on the Irish coastline when he was found by the Johnstone family who named him Julius Cesar.Peter Williams, curator at Exploris Aquarium, has worked closely with JC since his arrival.He explained about the turtlersquos journey back to good health.ldquoWhen JC arrived at the aquarium, the turtle was in a critical condition and we were unsure on whether or not it would pull through, he said. ldquoThankfully with expert around the clock care, it wasnrsquot too long until JC was out of the woods.ldquoOnly weighing a mere .kg when he arrived, JC has been feeding well on a iety of fish and invertebrates. We are now happy to report that the turtle weighs almost kg and his shell is almost cm.Peter added: ldquoWe are very pleased with the progress JC is making here at Exploris Aquarium and we have no doubts that this will continue. Hopefully next year we will be able to release JC back to the ocean.Exploris Aquarium also works to rehabilitate sick and abandoned seals which are found on the Northern Ireland coastlines..prettyPhoto

title: Nurses set to strike twice next week for better pay
story: LOCAL nurses are set to strike again next Wednesday and Friday as part of the continuing campaign for better pay and increased staffing levels.On Thursday, December , nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals braved atrocious weather conditions as they manned the picket line outside the entrance to the Downshire Civic Centre at the Ardglass Road in the town.Staff based at the Downe and Downshire hospitals took part in the protest and were joined by Ambulance Service staff, with their colleagues at all the provincersquos hospital taking part in the -hour strike.Hours before the industrial action commenced, Sinn Fein, DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance politicians met the head of Northern Irelandrsquos civil service, David Sterling, and Department of Health permanent secretary Richard Pengelly to try to avert the strike.In addition, the politicians also sent a joint letter to the Secretary of State, Julian Smith, expressing collective support for the restoration of pay parity.No progress was made and the strike went ahead as planned.Now local nurses are preparing to go back on strike next week, with the news confirmed recently by the Royal College of NursingrsquosNorthern Ireland Director, Pat Cullen.According to the RCN, nursesrsquo pay in Northern Ireland has fallen in real terms by % over eight years, aggravating a shortage of about , nurses, a vacancy rate proportionally higher than England and Wales.Health workers want pay parity with their counterparts in England, Scotland and Wales. Health unions agreed a .% three-year pay rise for NHS staff, excluding doctors, in  but the deal did not apply to Northern Northern because of the absence of devolved government.Nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals were among an estimated , from the Royal College who went on strike for the first time in the unionrsquos -year history the week before Christmas.The one-day stoppage marked a serious escalation after weeks of industrial action by other healthcareworkers. RCN nurses were joined by their Unison colleagues on the picket line in poor weather, buffeted by wind and rain.Northern Ireland has the worst hospital waiting lists in the UK, according to figures from the Department of Health with some , people waiting for appointments. On average, there is a four-year wait for knee and hip operations.The December  strike mdash which placed pressure on a range of hospital services and resulted in planned out-patient procedures and appointments being cancelled mdash placed increasing pressure on politicians restore the power-sharing assembly and executive at Stormont.During the industrial action, nurses did provide cover to ensure chemotherapy, intensive care and palliative care services at hospitals remained in place, while district nurses only attended emergency calls. A small number of domiciliary home calls were also cancelled.According to the South Eastern Trust,  outpatient appointments were cancelled and , others were not scheduled due to the recent industrial action.Ms Cullen said the local health service could not survive another winter, without improved pay and conditions for NHS staff.ldquoThe health service is in crisis, the senior RCN official continued.ldquoWe have , people on the waiting list for a hospital appointment and we have a severe nursing shortage, which is highlighted by the Nursing and Midwery Council figures.ldquoOur members have been out on strike to fight for patient safety and to improve conditions for everyone. Quite simply, we cannot afford to wait any longer to address the problems facing the health service. Another winter like this and the health service will be irreparably damaged..prettyPhoto

title: Seals prosper in Strangford Lough
story: STRANGFORD Lough is proving to be a popular nursery for grey seals.The largest sea inlet in Ireland can boast having  pups born in its waters during last autumn, the most since records began almost  years ago.The National Trust, which records the number of wildle visiting the area, revealed there were  adults in the lough at the peak of the breeding season last year ndash something of a turnaround for the protected species.In the early s records show that only around six or seven grey seals were born in the area each year.Lead ranger at Strangford Lough Hugh Thurgate say several factors have contributed to the growth in numbers.He said: ldquoThe boom reflects the burgeoning population in Scottish waters which is pushing the population down the North Channel and into the Irish Sea and seals are being forced to seek out new places to breed.ldquoThe shelter of Strangford is a strong draw for seals on the look-out for alternative spots to relax on shore during the breeding and moulting seasons.Mr Thurgate agrees that Strangford Lough is just the place for them.He added: ldquoThe seals are looking for a safe and protected place to raise their young ndash somewhere that provides protection from the elements and is relatively free from disturbance ndash which Strangford Lough offers.ldquoPups are quite vulnerable. Seals give birth on the beach andyou get stormy weather, tidal surges and high spring tides, high pup vitalities can occur because seals are unable to thermo-regulate properly.ldquoSo,you have calmer conditions pups are going to have a better chance of survival.The mild lough islands of Strangford are a favourite spot for the seals to haul out in large groups, known as rockeries, now a regular sight for boat users.Mr Thurgate, who has worked on Strangford Lough for two decades, has seen the population steadily rise.He said: ldquoWe starting counting seals in . And in , rsquo and rsquo the Trust recorded extremely low numbers of grey seals. Then slowly but surely they increased and by the mid-noughties there were around .ldquoThen it jumped quite signicantly and by  we had  pups for the first time. In  they went passed  mdash we actually recorded  that year.However, the common seal, cousin to the grey seal, isnrsquot enjoying the same kind of success on the lough.The changeable summer weather, followed by deluges and floods in November, proved challenging and the total population is now alarmingly low at under ..prettyPhoto

title: Students continue to excel on school’s 60th anniversary
story: THE th anniversary prize distribution at St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, was held before the Christmas break.The principal and staff were honoured to be joined by the guest speaker, Sister Teresa Clancy, who was one of the first members of the teaching staff when the school opened its doors in .Sister Teresa remained in St Malachyrsquos for her entire teaching career and served as vice-principal, demonstrating her commitment to the children and families of the area.The principal, Mrs Orla OrsquoNeill, began by congratulating the prize winners on being recognised for their admirable achievements throughout the past year.She told them: ldquoSt Malachyrsquos High School is all about fulfilling potential. We balance the academic and pastoral needs and wants of the students so they can achieve successful outcomes. Tonight affords us the opportunity to focus our attention on those many achievements of our students, our staff and our community.ldquoI am very privileged and honoured as principal to be a part of this wonderful school that has produced such high calibre students, who have all moved on from success to success and who represent all that is great about inclusive Catholic education.ldquoThe curriculum that we offer our students is the same as all post primary schools. However, we provide this in a schoolcommunity where all young people can learn and achieve together.Mrs OrsquoNeill stated with pride that St Malachyrsquos students continue to excel on the academic front with GCSE students once again producing record breaking results, with % of students achieving A*-C grades in five or more subjects and  students achieving seven or more A*-C grades and many achieving nine,  and  GCSEs.She said the quality of results had increased with many students securing several A* and A grades across the board in a wide range of subjects.Turning to A-Levels, she results attained ldquocontinue to be up there with the best.She said % of students three A-Levels at grades A*-C. A third of all grades were A* or A with % leaving St Malachyrsquos with three good A-Level passes.She said the percentage of St Malachyrsquos students going on to university was well above the Northern Ireland average.Guest speaker Sister Teresa captivated her audience, in particular the students who found her words inspirational.In a good-honoured address full of anecdotes and words of wisdom she recalled her daysas teacher and vice-principal fondly. Her nostalgic tone showed the audience just how much pride she took in being a part of the foundations of St Malachyrsquos as a teacher in .She spoke of the beginnings of St Malachyrsquos High School and how the amalgamation of the boysrsquo and girlsrsquo school came about.She referred to former principals and teachers and her memories of how the St Malachyrsquos community came to fruition since . She congratulated pupils, past and present for their outstanding achievements of the past year and beyond.She called St Malachyrsquos a ldquohighly motivated school with everyone working with and for each other.Her words of wisdom were to the pupils themselves. She advised them to talk to someone. She said she understood the demands of modern le and the stress it can have on young people. She advised the audience to reach out and reminded them that they were not alone.She reminded everyone to live by the gospel message and to treat others as they would like to be treated..prettyPhoto

title: Ulster Rugby stars muscle in to help at Downpatrick foodbank
story: ULSTER Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas came together to bring some festive cheer and extra support to a food bank and a youth centre in Downpatrick.Senior team players Nick Timoney, Jack McGrath and Kieran Treadwell helped out with packing and distributing food parcels for families across the area at the Fountain Foodbank at their busiest time of the year.Volunteer co-ordinator Shirley Lennon said she was delighted to have some extra muscle.She added: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the generosity of the local community for our foodbank appeal which helped support over  families across Downpatrick over Christmas.ldquoThe volunteers were fantastic and we were very glad to have had a team of strong helpers who made light work of moving so many Christmas parcels.A second team of Ulster Rugby senior team volunteers, Stuart McCloskey and Billy Burns, made their way to Patrician Youth Centre to take part in a rugby mini skills session with  pupils from Our Lady and St Patrickrsquos Primary School, before answering questions from the young people attending.Yvonne Maguire, manager of the Patrician Youth Centre, praised the players for their involvement.She said: ldquoFor many of the children this was their first time getting involved with rugby but the players put everyone at ease, getting involved in the session themselves and just encouraging them all to have fun mdash which they did. We would like to say a big thank you to Ulster Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas for this fantastic opportunity.The sessions were organised as part of the Ulster Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas LineOut programme which sees both organisations working together to make a real dference for communities across the Province.Jonathan Martindale, executive director at Phoenix Natural Gas, added: ldquoMaking a genuine dference for people and communities is at the heart of the LineOut Programme for ourselves and our partners at Ulster Rugby and we are delighted to have been able to offer our support to Fountain Foodbank and Patrician Youth Centre this Christmas..prettyPhoto

story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: view senedd vaughan gething
story: It is an issue that features heavily in my assembly postbag.I have been contacted by a number of local residents who are concerned about the availability of GP or other health care professionals for an appointment.The recent National Survey results showed continued concern over access with  per cent of participants finding it dficult to make an appointment at their practice.However  per cent of us were happy with our last episode of local healthcare.The NHS is facing unprecedented challenges with rising demand, expectation and long term public health challenges.We face those challenges against a backdrop of austerity imposed by the UK Government.I have previously spoken about our investment in community pharmacy, mental health counselling and physiotherapy services as key parts of local healthcare.We are though all aware of the pressures on our hardworking GPs and their practice teams to meet demand.I am incredibly proud of all our NHS staff who do a fantastic job despite the challenges they face.There is no single solution to improving access and a number of initiatives are underway including poundm invested in this yearrsquos contract with GPs.I am confident that we will help to relieve pressure on our GPs whilst also meeting the publicrsquos expectation.Last week, I was delighted to announce that the Train Work Live scheme has once again helped to exceed our targets for GP training.I launched the scheme in  to promote Wales as an excellent place for doctors and their families to train, work and live.We know that there are very real challenges across about recruiting and retaining GPs. This is not unique to Wales but an issue across the UK.Itrsquos important we act to ensure that our health service is sustainable in the long term.Recent figures show excellent progress has been made again this year.I increased the number of GP training places from  to  this year.However we actually filled  places.This is an increase of  per cent on last year and is great news for us locally.In order to ensure that we can recruit the medical workforce our health service needs now and in the future we also need to look outside Wales. That is why I recently visited India.The British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin have led the Medical Training Initiativescheme to bring medical professionals from India to work in NHS Wales for up to two years.This partnership with NHS Wales has led to over  doctors a year for the last three years being offered positions in NHS Wales through the scheme.During my visit I had the pleasure of meeting with some of the candidates who have applied to train work and live in Wales for two years together with the NHS Wales recruitment team.Our message that Wales is an excellent place to Train, Work and Live is clearly having an effect at home and abroad.As ever, I would be interested on hearing your views on this, please do get in touch. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE Vale Foodbank is calling for candidates on all sides to pledge to protect people from hunger.The call comes after it was revealed , emergency food parcels were given to people in the Vale between April  and September  this year.Of this number,  went to children.The figures are a  per cent increase on the same period last year.The Vale Foodbank is part of the Trussell Trustrsquos network, which announced that the need for emergency food parcels in the UK is at an all-time high.The new figures come after the Trussell Trust released State of Hunger, the most in-depth study ever published into hunger and the drivers of food bank use in the UK.The findings revealed the average weekly income of people at food banks is only pound after paying housing costs, and almost one in five have no money coming in at all in the month before being referred for emergency food.The Vale Foodbank is backing the Trussell Trustrsquos call for candidates on all sides to work towards a future where no one needs a food bank and pledge to protect people from hunger by ensuring everyone has enough money for the basics.The Trussell Trust is asking our next government to end the five week wait for universal credit ensure benefit payments cover the cost of living and invest in local emergency support for people in crisis.The local increase in need for the food bank is due to people struggling with the five-week wait for a first universal credit payment and people receiving payments that donrsquot cover the cost of essentials.Vale Foodbank trustee, Susan Lloyd-Selby said: ldquoItrsquos a real concern that in just six months wersquove provide , emergency supplies to local people.ldquoThese figures donrsquot take into account our busiest time of year - as the colder weather draws in, we often find even more people needing our help.ldquoWe believe that everyone should have enough money coming in to cover the basics. But right now, more and more people in the Vale are being forced to our food bankrsquos doors.ldquoThis isnrsquot right.ldquoWhile our help is needed, wersquore dedicated to ensuring that people in our community without enough money for food are able to access emergency support.ldquoOur vital work in the community has only been possible because of the incredible generosity shown by local people who have donated food, time and funds.ldquoThank you.The Vale Foodbank is particularly in need of UHT milk, fruit juice, tinned meat, and tinned vegetables.The charity has asked for festive donations to be donated in early December at the latest, to ensure volunteers have enough time to process and distribute these donations to people before Christmas. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: The team included Marie Curie nurses, volunteers, and family members of those cared for by the charity, with the proceeds going to people in need across the country - including Penarthrsquos own Marie Curie hospice.They tackled demanding daily hikes of up to eight hours and took on the valleys and paddy fields of northern Vietnam.Lisa Richards, a Marie Curie nurse from Rhuddlan, was part of the group and has raised more than pound, for the charityrsquos services across Wales.Ms Richards has been working for the charity for almost  years and lost six stone in preparation for the challenge.She said: ldquoI am always amazed by the fantastic fundraisers who work tirelessly giving their time and energy to raise money for the charity, so thatrsquos why this year I wanted to be a part of that process.ldquoI was supported every step of the way on the trek by a fantastic group of people who lted me up when I stumbled and made me feel like Irsquod known them forever and Irsquove really made friends for le.Mariclare Carey-Jones, a BBC journalist and broadcaster and ambassador for the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale hospice, took part in the challenge.ldquoAs an ambassador for the Vale hospice I know how important fundraising is in order to ensure the organisation can continue providing vital care and support for people with terminal illnesses and their families, she said.ldquoKnowing I could give something back to this fantastic charity that has done so much for me and my family was my main motivation for signing up to the Vietnam trek, while the opportunity to experience a new country and undertake an amazing challenge was a real added bonus.Now the charity is calling on people to sign up for its next trek to Patagonia, which will see funds raised for the Marie Curie Nursing Service across Wales - including care in the home and the hospice.Last year, Marie Curie nurses cared for more than , patients and their families across Wales, at a cost of more than poundm a year.Hannah Leckie, community fundraiser for Cardf and the Vale, said: ldquoOur treks are always very popular, whether itrsquos with people looking to take on a new challenge in a beautul country with stunning landscapes, or those whose family has been cared for at the hospice and want to give something back.ldquoWe think Patagonia could be the best adventure yet.ldquoIt will be offering all those taking part the trip of a letime while raising money for such an important local cause.To find out more about the Patagonia trek and to register your place, visit: https:tinyurl qpxnlf article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Ms Church now has permission to to open the school in her home in Dinas Powys.The Vale councils planning committee agreed to approve a planning application for the school this week.Part of the singers Awen Project, Ms Church has spoken of her hopes the project will soon start up more independent schools.As the Penarth Times previously reported, the former child star, musician, presenter and campaigner says she will pay for the school herself in its first year.It will be non fee-paying and will educate  children aged between nine and .Ms Church has said that the school would be aimed at children struggling in mainstream education, and offer pupils more of a say in their curriculum.Vale councillors were told the singer had begun teaching in her home two months ago, and that the application was therefore retrospective.The councillors were further told that the school would only be held in the Ms Churchs home for one year and the singer has agreed to the condition to find a new home for it by July  - with five options already shortlisted.The Vale councils highways department did not have any objections to the school and councillors approved the application. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale council announce new victorian style lampposts replace old ones
story: This follows claims from a civic group that the original lampposts were structurally safe.As the Penarth Times previously reported, Victorian lampposts across Penarth were being replaced earlier this year with modern LED lighting, with the Vale council citing concerns the existing posts were structurally unsafe.The removal of the posts prompted a community backlash. More than , people signed a petition to save the Victorian lamp posts, fearing a ldquoloss of valuable historic character from the streetscape in Penarth.A Vale council spokesman said: "ldquoThe council has recently approved a more suitable replacement column for the old Victorian lampposts which will be painted black and feature embellishments to match the Victorian period style as well as having a swan neck arrangement that will accommodate a suspended LED lantern to meet its energy reduction strategy. It is intended to roll out this replacement column by replacing the previously installed steel columns along Cwrt y Vil Road before the end of this calendar year."Penarth Civic Society alleged the posts were safe in a letter sent last week to the Vale councilrsquos head of visible services and council leader Neil Moore.David Noble of the Penarth Civic Society said: ldquoWe would like to ask that the programme of removal and replacement of Victorian lampposts in Penarth is suspended with immediate effect.ldquoWe are completely in favour of the councilrsquos policy to replace old inefficient street lighting with modern more energy efficient LED lighting units. However, we are firmly of the opinion that not enough effort has gone into the decision.ldquoIt seems that the council is spending over pound, on replacing each lamppost. When two posts in Kymin Terrace and Beach Lane were converted, the contractor expressed concern that the spigot on the column was not strong enough to support the new unit. We believe this remains the sole justication for the claim the units are unsound.ldquoWe have been in contact with several street lighting contractors. They have all confirmed as long as the posts are structurally sound at their base there is no reason they cannot be upgraded.ldquoWe feel the decision to scrap the old columns was taken prematurely, without proper consideration and is motivated by a desire for expedience rather than sensibility and care.A Vale council spokesman said: ldquoThe council has a duty to ensure that the street lighting is in a safe condition and does not pose a hazard to the general public. As a result, a number of the older Victorian lampposts in Penarth were recently replaced because they were considered electrically and structurally unsafe with holes evident in some columns. Given the many safety concerns with these old columns it was not practical or cost-effective to attempt repairs and maintain appropriate level of public safety.ldquoThe council is confident the new replacement columns will address many of the concerns previously raised and enable the remaining unsafe Victorian cast iron columns throughout Penarth to be sympathetically replaced in , preserving the character and nature of the roads and streets which currently benefit from the visual appearance of the old Victorina cast iron columns.ldquoWhile the new replacement columns with embellishments and swan neck are more expensive than standard columns the cost will be offset by conversion to LED lanterns with signicant environment benefits as they produce less Co and will be more economical to operate over the letime of the new units. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view senedd andrew rt davies
story: Trains are often cancelled or subject to severe delays, and when they arenrsquot passengers travel on rolling stock almost  years old.The Welsh Assembly have long promised an end to the ldquopacer trains that were introduced in the s as a stopgap - actually made of bus parts.When the new Transport for Wales franchise began last year, Welsh transport minister Ken Skates promised us ldquoquick wins. Sadly, these ldquowins have not been quick, yet to become a reality.Penarth commuters are still being shuttled into work each morning on overcrowded pacers, and this is simply not good enough. The new rolling stock we were promised seems many years away, when the reality is we need it now. Welsh Government need to pull their finger out and sort this out. Transport is their responsibility and they need to get a grip of the situation.The controversial Barry incinerator is a saga that seems to be rumbling on and on. I have long held deep concerns about the site, with the minister responsible for making the decision indicating almost two years ago she was ldquominded to insist an Environmental Impact Assessment be carried out.This week in the Assembly, I raised these concerns yet again, and the minister confirmed that an Environmental Statement has been submitted by the developer and is currently being reviewed. She claimed NRW are monitoring compliance throughout the testing phase, and that this is the latest position.Locally, there have been several apparently unconfirmed rumours that the site will be up and running in a matter of days, and I was disappointed the minister failed to give a categorical answer on this. I have always said the site is wholly unsuitable, and the Welsh Assembly have let local people down in their handling of this.I was very pleased last week to see a statement from Cardf and the Vale Health Board dropping controversial plans to close the Sam Davies ward at Barry Hospital. Under the proposals, the  bed ward was to close, with services transferred to the Heath and Llandough. While I welcome the announcement, they also confirmed new proposals will be brought forward this week. Given the statement did not include explicit commitment to keep the ward open, I fear we will see a rehashed version of the same plans in the near future. It has not been a good month for the Welsh NHS, with recent figures confirming wait times were joint worst on record. Irsquom calling for a cast iron guarantee from them that under the revised plans, the ward will remain open. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: view senedd vaughan gething
story: There was plenty of activity to be enjoyed to kick-start the Christmas festivities, from fairground rides and live music to refreshments and dance performances ndash we were even lucky enough to receive a visit from Father Christmas and his reindeer!The big man also had the honour of switching on the townrsquos Christmas lights.It was great to see so many residents attend the festivities. It is events like this in the very heart of Penarth which demonstrate how lucky we are to have such a ying and vibrant collection of businesses, which are so accessible.It was great to witness how the streets opened up to more traditional businesses of selling hand-crafted Christmas gts and roasted chestnuts, adding to the selection of businesses we already have on offer.Many of you will be aware of Small Business Saturday, which this year falls on December . The campaign aims to encourage people to ldquoshop local and to support small businesses in their communities.For me, one of the highlights of living in Penarth is access to a vibrant High Street. The street, and town as a whole, provides such a iety there really isnrsquot any need to go anywhere .I regularly make use of shops on the High Street, particularly the greengrocers and butchers, while my we, Michelle, makes use of others. Shopping locally you are almost always guaranteed to receive a first-class service with a smile, and it is that welcome, as well as the quality of the product or service, that keeps customers coming back ndash these are the reasons I always make thattrip.Thatrsquos why Irsquove got behind our local shops for this yearrsquos Small Business Saturday. In the run up to Small Business Saturday I have been visiting businesses across the constituency to talk to local business owners about them, their staff, what they enjoy about running their own business and the challenges that they face.On Friday December  I will be visiting businesses across Penarth. If you would like me to visit your business then please get in touch with my office on    or by emailing vaughan.gething@assembly.wales.Irsquod like to take this opportunity to thank the town council, as well as all its partners in organising the lights switch-on this year. story: A Freedom of Information request by Confused.Com found that , drivers were caught, with  in December alone.South Wales saw the highest number of drink-driving offences with , motorists caught drink-driving in the area.And further research from the car insurance comparison website found that  per cent of motorists would feel safe driving after two or more drinks.ldquoWith many of us enjoying celebrations with friends and family, we need to clue up on the drink-drive laws, as itrsquos clear so many people are taking the risk and driving after a drink, said Amanda Stretton, motoring editor at Confused.The drink-driving limit in England, Wales and Northern Ireland is  milligrams of alcohol per  millilitres of blood.:According to Confusedrsquos poll of , adults, more than halfof over s admitted to driving after drinking when it comes to the sexes, men are almost three times more likely to be prosecuted for drink-driving compared to women.And while drivers leave an average of eight hours before driving the night before, nearly two in fiveof drivers who were over the limit drove the morning after, assuming the alcohol had worn off.Ms Stretton added: ldquoSurprisingly, the morning after seems to be a prime time for drink-drivers.ldquoBut how long do we need to wait before we can drive ldquoWorking out units versus hours passed is confusing at the best of times, so wersquove released our morning after calculator to estimate when you should be safe to drive."You can try the calculator by clicking here.Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
